Award.AwardTitle: CMG RESEARCH: Combining Adjoint Tomography and Sparse Imaging Methods in Seismology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is on inverse problems in seismography.
Inferring undergound structure from seismic measurements is a nonlinear problem that is also notoriously ill-posed. The PIs will tackle this problem in its full nonlinearity via the adjoint method, by iteratively minimizing a variational functional in which, at each iteration step, the nonlinear effects of the approximate solution are fully taken into account for the computations in the next iteration.
To deal with the ill-posedness of the problem, they will use a regularization method that incorporates efficient modeling of spatial distributions that can exhibit discontinuities as well as smooth behavior between discontinuous transitions. More precisely, they will model the distribution as a sparse superposition of wavelets and curvelets, and add the sum of the absolute values of the corresponding expansion coefficients as a penalty term to the variational functional to be minimized. The inclusion of such a term enforces the sparseness of the expansion, thus expressing the smoothness of the model between discontinuous transitions, and has been proved to be regularizing. Computational resources have reached the speed and scale at which it is now feasible to use this approach for realistic problems.

Seismology seeks to gain insight into underground geological structure by measurements done at the surface. When vibrational signals are sent into the ground (whether by earthquakes, carefully tailored explosions or specially constructed vibrators), they propagate at different speeds through layers of different constitution, and are reflected at the often abrupt transitions between different layers. The goal of seismology is to reconstruct the underground structure traversed by these seismic waves from the complex signals, registered by seismographs, that result from the multiple reflections and their interaction. The corresponding numerical problem is of such great complexity that it has been necessary, in the past, to simplify it so as to keep the problem feasible; this led, of necessity, to approximate solutions. The PIs will make use of recent mathematical advances that make it possible to model more effectively heterogeneous underground structures, and of the continuing progress in speed of computational resources to tackle the problem without having to introduce some of the restrictive simplifications used previously. This is expected to result in more accurate maps of underground structure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When powerful earthquakes shake our planet, the waves they cause are felt in seismic stations worldwide. In their travels to these seismic stations, the seismic waves penetrate deep into the Earth's mantle and core, and upon their arrival, the traces registered bear the signature not only of the earthquake source itself, but also of the many heterogenous regions through which the waves traveled. The heterogeneity is either of temperature or composition, and registered in their influence on seismic wave-speed variations - hot regions or those with traces of melt slow down waves, whereas cold and dense regions lead to faster wave-speed propagation. We can compute what would be measured if the waves had traversed a completely spherically symmetric Earth (in which the variations of seismic velocity are only with depth in the Earth, but do not vary with longitude and latitude at fixed depths); by comparing the actual measurements with these theoretical computations, we can deduce differences between the spherical reference model and the Earth, including possible plumes rising up from the core through the mantle, subduction zones that generate powerful earthquakes, mid-ocean ridges where new crust is formed, and other local anomalies. Resolving these local anomalies requires a mathematical tool and corresponding algorithms that can model and compute efficiently structures that have features at many different scales, from maybe 100 to several thousands of km in diameter. Part of the research supported by this grant concerned the development of such a mathematical tool, with which the computations were ultimately brought to a good end. The combination of new mathematical building blocks for the parameterization of Earth models (three-dimensional spherical wavelets) with dedicated algorithms that find solutions (the Earth model) expressed in this basis (the wavelet basis) that match the data (the seismograms) is a very powerful tool to achieve maximum data fit with a minimum amount of redundancy. We compared the behavior of our so-called "sparsity-seeking inversion methods" with more traditional techniques, and applied them to the analysis of various data sets, including a large set of earthquake data recorded by the USArray component of the EarthScope program. The research that we have done combined geophysics, signal processing, applied mathematics, and also computer science: for our final applications we used powerful clusters of parallel computers to make detailed images of the interior of the Earth. Our techniques are useful to the oil and gas industry, which relies heavily on seismic wavefield inversion to image reservoirs, and we have made a first foray in the application of our techniques to exploration-size problems. Here, as in the global problem, the emphasis is on using as much of the data as possible (in the oil industry, those would be billions of traces) in a computationally and mathematically as efficient a way as possible. Our research has opened new avenues of research in (academic) global seismology, (industrial) exploration seismology, and other areas such as medical imaging, with concrete results in the form of algorithms, code, information of Earth structure below the North American continent, and technology to use a much large piece of the wavefield recorded in seismic, acoustic, and medical imaging techniques.
